name: Turkey Tamales
headline: Turkey Tamales
keywords: Poultry,Turkey Recipes,Main Dish,Cinco de Mayo,Gluten Free,High Fiber
recipeIngredient: 1 1/2 teaspoons freshly toasted and ground cumin seeds
1 serrano chile, seeded and finely minced

recipeInstructions.text: Place chili powder, cumin, cayenne pepper, oregano, salt, black pepper and turkey legs into a 6-quart pot and add enough water to completely cover the meat, approximately 2 1/2 quarts. Cover, place over high heat and bring to a boil. Once boiling, reduce the heat to low and simmer until the meat is very tender and falling apart, 1 1/2 to 2 hours. Remove the meat from the water to a cutting board, and set aside to cool. Leave the cooking liquid in the pot. Once the turkey legs are cool enough to handle, remove the meat from the bone and shred, discarding any skin or cartilage. Place a 4-quart saucepan over medium heat and add the vegetable oil. Once shimmering, add the onion and cook, stirring occasionally, until they are semi-translucent, approximately 2 minutes. Add the garlic and chili and continue to cook for another minute. Add the meat and 1/2 cup of the reserved cooking liquid and cook until heated through and the liquid has evaporated, 2 to 3 minutes. Set aside until ready to assemble.

While the meat is cooking, place the husks in a large bowl or container and submerge completely in hot water. Soak the husks until they are soft and pliable, at least 45 minutes and up to 2 hours. If you have an electric kettle, place the husks in the kettle, fill with water and turn on. Once the kettle turns off, allow the husks to sit for 1 hour in the hot water.

Place the masa, salt, and baking powder into a large mixing bowl and combine. Add the lard and using your hands, knead together until the lard is well incorporated into the dry mixture. Gradually add enough of the reserved cooking liquid, 2 to 4 cups to create a dough that is like thick mashed potatoes. The dough should be moist but not wet. Cover the bowl with a damp towel and set aside until ready to use.

Remove a corn husk from the water and pat to remove excess water. Working in batches of 6, lay the husks on a towel and spread about 2 tablespoons of the dough in an even layer across the wide end of the husk to within 1/2-inch of the edges. Spoon about 2 teaspoons of the meat mixture in a line down the center of the dough. Roll the husk so the dough surrounds the meat and fold the bottom under to finish creating the tamale. Repeat until all the husks, dough and filling are used. Tie the tamales, around the center, individually or in groups of 3, with kitchen twine.

Place a steamer basket in the bottom of an 11-quart pot and add enough water to come to the bottom of the basket. Stand the tamales close together on their folded ends and lean them in towards the center, away from the sides of the pot. Bring the water to a boil over medium heat, then cover and reduce the heat to maintain a simmer. Check the water level every 15 to 20 minutes, and add boiling water by pouring down the side of the pot, if necessary. Steam until the dough is firm and pulls away from the husk easily, 1 to 1 1/2 hours.
Serve warm. Store leftover tamales, tightly wrapped in plastic wrap, in the freezer, for up to a month. To reheat, remove the plastic wrap and steam until heated through.

review.reviewBody: I have to say I love this simple recipe. I am use to making red chile tamales and was skeptical of this recipe. My family loved it and so did my coworkers. I would say these are the easiest tamales I have ever made. I will be keeping this recipe around. Side note: I am Latina and so are most of my coworkers. We were all impressed with these tamales. Most of my co-workers had never tried turkey tamales. Will be doing these for Christmas from now on. Fantastic!!

These looked amazing on tv. In the episode, he mentioned they were made with turkey as that's the bird that was available at the time. No pigs or cows until the European invasion. So what did they use in place of lard at the time? I was surprised he didn't explain as usually he's very thorough.

These tamales are amazing. This was my first attempt at homemade tamales, and they are some of the best I have ever had. For a bonus, use the remaining cooking liquid, and make soup. Add some corn, peas, cumin, cayenne, rice (like 1/4 to 1/2 cup), and masa balls (make the masa recipe, just don't press out). Awesome no-waste dinner or side.

Here's an interesting tip: Double up on the dough portion of this recipe. From the extra dough, scoop out ⅓ cup portions.Take half of these portions and store in the 'fridge. Take the other half and wrap to freeze. Now, any time you want, take a ⅓ cup portion and cut it in half. Flatten each half into a flat, level disk. Add a little of any filling you want then top with the other half, pressing the disk edges to seal. Now, toss a filled disk on a lightly oiled skillet over medium heat. Check the bottom every 2 minutes or so. When it JUST start to brown (about 2-3 minutes, flip and repeat on the other side. You just made an El Salvadorean pupusa!
I used pork and upped the spice a bit and I've got to say, these were amazing.  I'll be surprised if the 4 dozen lasts three days.
I like the recipe, but I would NOT rate it "Easy" when it takes 5 hours and a lot of preparation.

WOW WOW WOW!!!!! I had never made tamales before this recipe.  Had never eaten one.  Followed Alton's directions.  WOW!  People actually beg me to make tamales for them!  They claim thay have never tasted better.  The sauce is also key.  You rock Alton!  P.S.  If I tell my husband I am going to make them and I don't... He sulks for days.

Love it! First time making tamales, and they turned out brilliantly. Turkey "not in season" so I used chicken thighs, and instead of store bought lard I used bacon fat, which I filter and save in a mason jar in the fridge. Also, I added some of the schmaltz (chicken fat, from the poaching to the oil used in the saute.

This turned out perfect, and was even loved by a certain picky eater I know! :D
Do yourself a favor and try this recipe soon.

Just watching Alton on his show,..he deserves the five stars!  He is excellent, and covers every detail, and is so funny I could watch his shows all day!! Excellent chef...and I am going back to "Lard" just because of his tip!  Thanks Alton!

Finally! Managed to get corn husks in an isolated part of Canada that didn't cost an arm and a leg!

Been waiting to try this recipe for a very, very long time. Well worth the wait! One tip I would pass along, if I may, is having a bowl of water next to your work station. Dip the heel of your hand in the water before trying to spread each ball of masa dough. It keeps it from sticking to your hand. All in all, it was a ton of fun to make and eat! Alton is the best, eh?

Fantastic! The only thing I did different was instead of putting the serrano chile in the filling, I put a chipotle chile in the water with the turkey legs, and then added that to the filling. I can't believe how good these are, even my picky husband liked them! Assembling them didn't take as long as I thought it would. I can't wait to freeze these and have them ready to pull out for weeknight dinners! I've learned so much from watching Good Eats, it's the best thing on television!
We usually make this recipe with crockpot roasts as turkey legs aren't available in our area. It is by far one of the best things I have ever ate.
I am shocked also...these are the BEST tamales I have ever had....if you could vote for 10 stars this recipe deserves it!  Fabulous!!!!
I am shocked to find that this recipe has only received 4 stars. These tamales are as good if not better than any you will find in a mexican restaurant. Definitely my favorite AB recipe.

i just made these (litterally) and im eating them now!!!

WONDERFUL WONDERFUL WONDERFUL Alton brown never disappoints :)

though it did take me like 4 days
Day1: Soak corn husk (fell asleep) make next day
Day 2: Never made
Day 3: Resoak husks and cook every thing only finished about 10 bundles
It was late so I just placed them in a container with a damp towel PLUS i had to make 2 batches of dough I ran out as I was finishing for what ever reason? maybe i made more than was supposed too i still had lots of meat left so I just made tamales until i had no more stuff left
Day 4: Finally cooked them :) and they r great!
Best tamales ever! we make these every year as a Thanksgiving tradition! they are a great appetiser while waiting for the bird to cook. thanks Alton!

I've been wanting to learn to make tamales for years, and I'm very happy with this recipe. "Demistifying", is right, to quote another reviewer. It really is simple, though potentially time consuming, as is all comfort food.

I only used the masa recipe and assembly instructions; for the filling I used a leftover crockpot pork roast and its cooking liquid. I did add the onion, garlic, and chili pepper as directed.

To those who find they need to double the spice ingredients - it's probably because AB buys his spices off the internet as fresh as he can. Grocery store spices are going to be about half as flavorful as good fresh spices.

I used the dough part of the recipe and filled with slow cooked pork (tomatillo, anaheims, onion, garlic, jalapeno and cilantro).  Followed the dough recipe exactly and it was FANTASTIC.  Literally at least as good as any tamale I have ever tasted.  Flat-out excellent recipe and perfect timing instructions.  Alton is annoying as heck, but this recipe is definitely a winner.
I couldn't believe how good they were, and after a little practice they're easy too! Make sure and grind your own cumin!

These take a considerable amount of work.  But, the end result is unlike anything I've had.  Alton is AWESOME!!  Thanks to him for giving such detailed instruction and wonderful recipes.  I will make these again.  My family loved them and they tasted so authentic.  I did the recipe exactly as written.
Alton is the man!!!! Great recipe as always....

I've been trying my best to make good tamales and have had some success. I was really happy to see AB do a show about these. Several of his common sense suggestions made the process way easier then the way I was trying to do it, especially the way of applying the masa to the husks by hand, and also tying them in bundles. I really liked the filling and these cost less to make and took less time then several of the recipes I've tried. They came out very much like restaurant style tamales with homemade goodness. One last thing, I really liked using the fresh aromatics in the filling.

Though they were a bit time difficult at first, I really liked these tamales. It's nice be able to make them when I like, and I can already think of lots of variations. And to the fly fisherman - as a surgeon I can tell you that the knot AB used is a surgeon's knot, and is used by surgeons whenever there is likely to be tissue strain at the suture line as this knots holds well by creating more friction. I'm not sure what you think is a surgeon's knot, but I assure you AB was right.
Yummy. And corn husks make very nice hats.

As a dedicated fly fisherman, I can tell you that the knot you show for tying the tamale/husk bundle together for this episode is not a surgeon's knot. The surgeon's knot (which, by the way, is not used by surgeons) is a variation of the simple double overhand knot (Granny knot) and would be difficult to tie without bringing the whole tamale back through a loop.

But don't worry, any knot will work for this application, as the string will swell and tighten up upon being steamed
After hours of fun chopping, simmering, and steamin' I got the pleasure to try these wonderful tamales. Very simple preparation, and easy to follow instructions, Alton Brown succeeds once again!

This recipe gets 4 out of 5 only because it's marked as "Easy" instead of "Intermediate." It's my first batch of tamales and involved a lot of attention while steaming. I had a bunch of chicken parts in the freezer that were intended for the stock pot, so this became the perfect application. I doubled the seasoning like everyone else did. I didn't have lard, so I used rendered bacon fat instead. Worked great, but it added a lot of salt. I used my large soup pot with a steam basket. The water boiled out very quickly and burned on the bottom. The tamales didn't take on the burn flavor, and the pot cleaned easily, so this wasn't a big annoyance. I ran out masa with a lot of chicken left over, and they came out less meaty than I would've liked, so I'm going to adjust proportions next time. And, just to echo fellow posters, thanks for demystifying this delicious dish!

I am obsessed with tamales and I have never made them before?until now.  These were the best ones I have ever eaten.  Believe me, do not underestimate this recipe, I can not express how fantastic these come out.  I did not veer from Alton?s recipe at all they are perfect.  I ate them with no toppings, dips, or anything and they almost made me fall down with the taste.

We each bagged a gobbler on our very first hunt this spring, but no amount of slow cooking would tenderize the thigh meat.  Wild turkeys are extreme athletes compared to the domestic variety.  Then I saw Alton's show and oh, yeah, the result was more than enough to justify the cost of the guide, licenses, tags, and camo outfits.  Turkeys are getting out of hand in our area, but no worry: we'll do our best to bring them under control.
great eats

My whole family including my picky grandkids loved these tamales.  My daughter in law took some to work and everyone wanted me to make them some.  LOL.  My daughter in law thought a friend had taught me how to cook them.  In reality, we had made 1 batch 15 years ago.  I forgot how to do it.  Alton's recipe was perfect.  My husband couldn't believe I got it from food network.

I just posted a really long and detailed review that the website said it was unable to publish at this time, so here's the short version.

Very good, needs way more spice than Alton said, time-consuming but worth the trouble, the masa harina is just great for those of us who can't get fresh, mine were delicious. I'm glad I made them. If you're in the Northeast, you can get corn husks at Shaw's market, the masa at Whole Foods. I bet you could use fresh corn husks too.

while simmering the spices,and turkey, the aroma reminded me of my grandmother and her cooking,  which would be from dawn to dusk. . always  preparing for the meal  ahead, and the  knowing that she enjoyed cooking for our family and friends.  while i am disappointed in not getting the recipe from her. It is the  cooking that makes it so special .  yes it was good

I love tamales but it had always looked so complicated. My sister-in-law got a group together years ago and we all spent the entire day "making" tamales - let's just say that perhaps the margarita's somehow were responsible for the masa that wound up on the ceiling and the walls of her kitchen. At the end of the day, we were exhausted and had little to show. I resolved NEVER to attempt to make tamales again because it was just too complicated. But after watching your episode on Tamale making, I was enlightened. You made it look so easy that I just had to try it myself. Oh my, they were so delicious! I couldn't find turkey legs so I used chicken and doubled the seasoning - my family loved them. And it only took 1 hour to cook the meat, assembly was EASY and 1 hour to steam them. Next, I'm going to make bison tamales - I love bison.
And in Texas, we know good tamales! Alton, many thanks for your recipe.
Dora
Houston, TX

Since I live in Tucson and in keeping with our Hispanic and native tradition we make tamales every Christmas. I agree with the poster who said to use fresh masa if avaiilable. Mixing dry is a misery. I don't tie either.

However, in Alton's defense, I can understand why he tied the tamales and mixed harina, etc. We had to move away from Tucson several years ago, "back east." No fresh mass available. The husks that were available were so bad that we had no choice but to tie. That is a misery too. The husks were small and probably left over from Father Kino's time, circa 1775.

My wife would never let me use our tea kettle to soak the husks. Besides if you have an extended family, a kettle will not hold enough. My wife also will not let me use lard. I don't think the consitency is as good with shortening.

i notice AB didnot put a Spanish olive in each tamale (complete with its seed). Is that unique to Arzona/Sonora?

Now that we are back in Tucson. Joy. Fresh masa. Good husks.

Thanks Alton for this episode.

steam up a batch of day-old tamales for breakfast with a good strong cup of your favorite dark roast coffee or if you like cafe du monde that's good with them, too. Alton's recipe is a lot like my mom and all the tias used to make every Christmas. The masa they prepared was a bit creamier, but other than that YUM!

I had never made tamales before trying this recipe, and while it wasn't the greatest recipe, it did help me understand the steps behind the process (like many Good Eats recipes).  I found, like many others, that the turkey filling was a little less spiced than I would have liked, but that is simple enough to alter.  If there was a 4 1/2 star rating, I would give it that instead.  I would suggest to those who like their filling more flavorful to add more spices to the filling part, after you have shredded the turkey, even if you are trying this recipe for the first time.

Thanks to Alton Brown for taking the mystery out of making tamales. My friend and I made them together one afternoon, and they came out great! I was so happy because I have wanted to try making them forever, but was a little intimidated. Alton Brown, you are my hero!!!!  Now that I have the basics down, i will try some experimentation with ingredients, maybe a little more spicy.
I have all ingredients except for corn husks.  I've been to Publix, Win-Dixe, and The Fresh Market and no one has them, so I'm probably going to order them online.

All the non-latinos were probably watching this episode with great interest and rightly so. The latinos (at the least the ones in the know) were probably laughing their heads off when Alton was doing the masa segment. I know I was!

People, do not get me wrong. I appreciate Alton's knowledge and I've learned a great deal from him. He is definitely someone at FN to be respected. This is why it pains me to write this.

ALTON DID NOT DO HIS HOMEWORK FOR THIS SEGMENT!!

Alton wanted to strive for an authenticity in this recipe by saying that the Mayans had no pigs, cows, or chickens. News flash, the Mayans didn't have bagged masa harina either!!

Folks, do yourselves a favor. If you live in a region where you have access to fresh masa from a Mexican market/restaurant, buy the appropriate poundage and continue with the directions making absolutely certain the lard is incorporated. If no such store exists, use the masa harina. HOWEVER, you must FIRST add just enough warm water to make a "dough". Let it rest for about an hour!! THEN continue on with the broth, lard, and so on mixing until you have the consistency of creamy peanut butter. You may have to add more broth to attain the proper consistency!

When properly cooked, you'll end up with a nice, soft, and warm tamale with the consistency of pumpkin pie!

The consistency shown in the broadcast will render a tamale perfect for a torpedo casing. Substitute gun powder and THE TALIBAN WOULD SURRENDER IN SECONDS with what Alton made.

Last note on tying the tamales, use larger husks and spread the masa over the upper portion leaving enough husk to fold up to the top of the tamale. TYING IS FOR SISSIES!!

Never tried making before because I thought it would be a big production. My sister-in-law's family makes tamales every Christmas and I look forward to getting some. Now I can make my own. They turned out as advertised. Very mild though, next time I will make spicier. When my sister-in-law makes them, they make different heat levels and a lot of them to give out. (my favorite Christmas cookie) The process was fun and easy.

Thanks
